questions.text: What is the correct order of presenting sequence in rigor mortis after death?

options.label: A
options.text: Fingers and toes → Upper limbs → Lower limbs →Abdomen

options.label: B
options.text: Upper limbs → Abdomen → Lower limbs → Fingers and toes

options.label: C
options.text: Lower limbs → Abdomen → Upper limbs →Fingers and toes

options.label: D
options.text: Fingers and toes → Upper limbs → Abdomen → Lower limbs

questions.correct_answer: B. Upper limbs → Abdomen → Lower limbs → Fingers and toes
questions.explanation:
Phase

Description

Timeframe
  1. Primary Relaxation
  • ATP levels are initially 100%, allowing muscle relaxation.
  • Sphincters relax, leading to the passage of feces and urine.

0 to 60 minutes after death
  1. Rigor Mortis Onset
  • Onset occurs around 60 minutes as ATP depletes to ~85%.
  • Muscles stiffen as actin and myosin filaments bind.
  • Maximum rigidity is reached approximately 12 hours postmortem, with significant stiffness noticeable, especially in larger muscles.

60 minutes to 12 hours after death
  1. Resolution
  • Following peak rigidity, a secondary relaxation phase begins as proteins decompose (proteolysis of actin-myosin).
  • Rigor mortis resolves completely after about 12 hours, leading to further decomposition.

12 to 24 hours after death

questions.text: A dead body is being examined by the forensic surgeon and maggots are found. Which of the following life stage of maggots is correctly matched with their time?

options.label: C
options.text: Adult fly formation from pupae: 1-2 days

questions.text: A 50-year-old female is found deceased in her home, and upon examination, it is noted that her stomach contains undigested food from a heavy meal. Based on the examination findings, what is the most likely time frame for the patient's death after her last meal?

A 50-year-old male passed away due to a myocardial infarction. The family requested embalming for preservation of the body before the funeral. Which of the following statements about embalming is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Produces permanent chemical rigidity that mimics rigor mortis.

options.label: B
options.text: Sodium citrate is used in embalming fluid as an anticoagulant.

options.label: C
options.text: Embalming makes it easier to interpret postmortem injuries.

options.label: D
options.text: Femoral artery is commonly used for injecting embalming fluid.

questions.correct_answer: C. Embalming makes it easier to interpret postmortem injuries.
questions.explanation:
Embalming
  • Aka thanatopraxia
  • Embalming is treatment of the dead body with antiseptics and preservatives to prevent putrefaction and preserve the body.

Effect

  • Produces chemical stiffening similar to rigor mortis, and normal rigor does not develop.
  • Embalming rigidity is permanent. (Option A)

Best Time

< 6 hours of death.

Best injection technique

Discontinuous injection and drainage.

Best vessel for injection

Femoral artery (Option C)

Best embalming technique

High pressure and low flow rate.

Skin color in Embalming
  • Jaundiced Bodies: Greenish discoloration
  • Normal Individual: Gray color

Methods of Embalming
  • Arterial embalming
  • Cavity embalming
  • Hypodermic embalming
  • Surface embalming

Disadvantages
  • Difficult to interpret any injury or disease. (Option C)
  • Determination of poisons becomes challenging.
  • Blood grouping may not be possible.
  • Thrombi and emboli may be dislocated/dislodged.

Medicolegal Importance
  • Embalming before autopsy in a medicolegal case invites liability under Section 201 IPC, causing the disappearance of evidence or giving false information to screen the offender.
  • Disrespecting the corpse can lead to applicability of Section 297 IPC.

Image

Preservative
  • Formalin
  • Methanol

Germicide

Phenol

Fungicide

Thymol

Buffer

Sodium borate

Anticoagulant

Sodium citrate (Option B)

Wetting agent

Glycerin

Controls pH

Sodium chloride

Cosmetic

Eosin

Perfume

Soluble wintergreen

Vehicle

Water

questions.text: Which of the following factors does not favour the process in the given image?

options.label: C
options.text: Contact of the body with water

questions.correct_answer: C. Contact of the body with water
questions.explanation:
Mummification

  • It is the rapid dehydration/desiccation and shriveling of the dead body from evaporation of water, with the preservation of natural appearances and features of the body.
  • It is a modification of putrefaction.

Features

  • Begins in the exposed parts of the body like the face, hands, and feet.
  • Then extends to the entire body and internal organs.
  • The skin may be translucent, shrunken, brittle, leathery, dry, and rusty-brown color.

Time for mummification

3-12 months or longer.

Factors favoring mummification
  • Hot environment. (Option A)
  • Dry atmosphere.
  • Free air movement. (Option B)
  • Contact of the body with absorbing media.
  • Poisoning: chronic arsenic or antimony poisoning favors the process. (Option D)

Medicolegal importance
  • Climate and time of death.
  • Determine the time of death.
  • Identification is easy.

Feature

Adipocere

Mummification

Characteristic feature

Conversion of fatty tissues into fatty acids

Dehydration or desiccation

Smell

Rancid smell

Odorless

Moisture

Gains moisture and undergoes hydrolysis

Loses moisture

Ideal conditions

Warm temperature, moisture, less air, bacteria, and fat

splitting enzymes

High temperature, dry condition, and free circulation

of air

questions.text: A forensic expert is examining a dead body that was found in a hot and moist place. There is adipocere formation all over the body including the internal organs. What does this finding signify? It gives a rough idea of the time since death It is formed due to postmortem hydrolysis and hydrogenation of saturated fats Organisms like aerobic bacteria help this process It is usually found in sites with fat deposits
questions.explanation:
Adipocere/Sponification

This is a change of decomposition where there is a development of an offensive, sweet rancid-smelling, soft, whitish, or grayish-white, crumbly, waxy, and greasy material (similar to soap) that occurs in fatty tissues of a dead body.

Time required for formation
  • Hot and humid environment: by the end of 1 week.
  • Temperate countries: starts after 3 weeks and ends by about 3 months.

Mechanism of formation

The formation of saturated fatty acids due to postmortem hydrolysis and hydrogenation of body fats leads to adipocere.

Sites

  • Usual sites:
    • Face, buttocks, breasts, and abdomen
  • Internal sites:
    • Small muscles turn gray and are dehydrated and thin
    • Large muscles are red/pink
    • Fat is completely converted to adipocere
    • Intestines and lungs are parchment-like
    • The liver is prominent and retains its shape

Factors influencing adipocere formation
  • Temperature: Heat speeds up, and cold retards adipocere formation
  • Moisture: Water helps with adipocere formation
  • Organisms: Bacteria like Clostridium perfringes and other anaerobes assist in the reaction by producing lecithinase
  • Built: Faster in mature newborns and obese people
  • Age: Fetuses <7 months do not show adipocere
  • Air current: Retards adipocere formation
  • Running water: Retarded due to wash out of electrolytes

Medicolegal importance
  • It is the surest sign of death.
  • Gives a rough estimate of the time of death.
  • Features of the face stay preserved and help in identification.
  • Cause of death may be found as injuries might be preserved.
  • Some idea about the place of disposal can be made.

questions.text: According to Casper’s dictum, the rate of decomposition varies depending on the environment. Which of the following correctly represents this relationship?

options.label: A
options.text: Decomposition in deeply buried bodies is faster than in water.

options.label: B
options.text: Decomposition in water occurs at the same rate as in air.

options.label: C
options.text: Decomposition in air is faster than in soil.

options.label: D
options.text: Decomposition in air occurs eight times faster than in water.

questions.correct_answer: C. Decomposition in air is faster than in soil.

questions.text: A decomposing body is found in the woods. Upon examination, it is noted that the skull sutures have separated, and the skin on the hands and feet has sloughed off in a 'glove and stocking' manner. Liquefied brain matter is observed. What is the most likely time frame of death?
questions.explanation:
Feature Approximate Time Postmortem
Rigor mortis complete (Option A ruled out) 12–24 hours
Greenish discoloration of the abdomen (Option B ruled out) 24–48 hours
Marbling, bloating 2–4 days
Skin slippage begins (Option C ruled out) 3–5 days
Glove and stocking skin peeling 5–10 days
Liquefied brain and suture separation 5–10 days

questions.text: During an autopsy performed on a body 20 hours after death, the pathologist notices small blisters filled with gas on the lower abdomen and thighs. What is the likely cause of these blisters?
questions.correct_answer: B. Decomposition due to gas formation
questions.explanation:
Post-mortem blister
  • Gas formation in the blood vessels can push blood stained fluid, air, or liquid fat between the epidermis and dermis, leading to the formation of small blisters.
  • Occurs within 18 to 24 hours.
  • Blisters typically appear on the lower surfaces of the trunk and thighs, areas where hypostatic edema causes tissue fluid buildup.

Postmortem gas rigidity

  • It is also known as gas stiffening, this is when the body becomes rigid due to the accumulation of putrefactive gases.

Post mortem purge
  • Gas accumulation in the abdomen forces the diaphragm upwards compressing the lungs and heart, and the bloodstained froth exude from the mouth and nostrils.
  • This can be misinterpreted as bleeding from antemortem injury.

Features

Ante-mortem blister

Post-mortem blister

Cause

Burns (Option A)

Decomposition (Option B)

Content

Inflammatory fluid

Gas

Base

Hyperemia

Pale

Vital reaction

Present

Absent

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is found deceased in an apartment, and the body is examined 48 hours post-mortem. A distinct branching pattern is observed along the superficial blood vessels after 24 hours, as shown below. What is the most likely cause of the skin pattern observed in the image?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning Objective:
  • ➤ Feature Marbling Filigree Burns Nature Postmortem pattern in the skin caused by bacterial decomposition. Superficial thin, irregular and tortuous skin markings caused by lightning or electrical discharge. Onset Starts within 24 hours after death. Appears within minutes to an hour of the electrical accident. Colour Starts reddish-green and eventually dark green or black. Red Site of Occurrence Blood vessels Skin surface Medicolegal Importance Helps determine the time since death. Indicates electrical injuries or lighting. Image
  • ➤ Feature Marbling Filigree Burns
  • ➤ Nature Postmortem pattern in the skin caused by bacterial decomposition. Superficial thin, irregular and tortuous skin markings caused by lightning or electrical discharge.
  • ➤ Postmortem pattern in the skin caused by bacterial decomposition.
  • ➤ Postmortem pattern in the skin caused by bacterial decomposition.
  • ➤ Superficial thin, irregular and tortuous skin markings caused by lightning or electrical discharge.
  • ➤ Superficial thin, irregular and tortuous skin markings caused by lightning or electrical discharge.
  • ➤ Onset Starts within 24 hours after death. Appears within minutes to an hour of the electrical accident.
  • ➤ Starts within 24 hours after death.
  • ➤ Starts within 24 hours after death.
  • ➤ Appears within minutes to an hour of the electrical accident.
  • ➤ Appears within minutes to an hour of the electrical accident.
  • ➤ Colour Starts reddish-green and eventually dark green or black. Red
  • ➤ Starts reddish-green and eventually dark green or black.
  • ➤ Starts reddish-green and eventually dark green or black.
  • ➤ Site of Occurrence Blood vessels Skin surface
  • ➤ Site of Occurrence
  • ➤ Site of Occurrence
  • ➤ Site of Occurrence
  • ➤ Medicolegal Importance Helps determine the time since death. Indicates electrical injuries or lighting.
  • ➤ Medicolegal Importance
  • ➤ Medicolegal Importance
  • ➤ Medicolegal Importance
  • ➤ Helps determine the time since death.
  • ➤ Helps determine the time since death.
  • ➤ Indicates electrical injuries or lighting.
  • ➤ Indicates electrical injuries or lighting.

Marbling

Definition

Refers to a characteristic pattern in the skin caused by decomposition.

Mechanism

After death, bacteria spread through blood vessels, decomposing hemoglobin into sulfmethemoglobin, which causes greenish or reddish-brown staining of the vessel walls.

Pattern

Marbled pattern follows a linear branching pattern, resembling tree branches, which initially appears red and later transitions to a greenish hue.

Onset and Timing
  • Begins to develop 24 hours after death.
  • Becomes prominent by 36-48 hours.

Color Changes Over Time

Skin’s reddish-green marbling may turn dark green or nearly black within 3 to 4 days.

Areas of Marbling

Shoulders, roots of the limbs, thighs, sides of the abdomen, chest, and neck.

Medicolegal Importance

Helps in determining the time since death

Image

Feature

Marbling

Filigree Burns

Nature

Postmortem pattern in the skin caused by bacterial decomposition.

Superficial thin, irregular and tortuous skin markings caused by lightning or electrical discharge.

Onset

Starts within 24 hours after death.

Appears within minutes to an hour of the electrical accident.

Colour

Starts reddish-green and eventually dark green or black.

Red

Site of Occurrence

Blood vessels

Skin surface

Medicolegal Importance

Helps determine the time since death.

Indicates electrical injuries or lighting.

Image

questions.text: A body arrived at the forensic department for autopsy, presenting with distinct features, including a greenish discoloration of the abdomen, a strong odor, and gas formation within the tissues (as shown in the image provided below). What enzyme is primarily responsible for these characteristics?
questions.explanation:
Autolysis

Putrefaction

Autolysis is the self-digestion of tissues caused by the body’s own enzymes after death.

 

Characteristics of Autolysis:

  • Initiation: Begins immediately after death when metabolic processes cease.
  • Mechanism: Enzymatic action leads to cell lysis, altering tissue appearance and texture.
 

Examples of Autolytic Changes:

  • Clouding of the Cornea: The first observable external change, losing transparency due to cellular breakdown.
  • Changes in Brain Glandular Tissue: The first internal change, where neuronal and glial cells undergo lysis.
 

Note:

Aseptic Autolysis: Occurs in intrauterine fetal demise, leading to mummification without bacterial involvement.

Putrefaction is driven by bacterial activity, resulting in tissue breakdown and gas production.

 

Characteristics of Putrefaction:

  • Bacterial Involvement: Primarily caused by Clostridium perfringens.
  • Lytic Enzyme: The main enzyme involved is lecithinase, which breaks down cell membranes.
 

Stages of Putrefaction:

 
  1. Color Change:
  • The first internal change is reddish-brown discoloration of the aortic intima.
  • The first external change is green discoloration in the right iliac fossa due to the breakdown of hemoglobin.
 
  1. Mechanism of Color Change:
  • Hydrogen Sulfide Production: Bacteria produce hydrogen sulfide, which forms a green compound with hemoglobin.
  • The cecum is the primary site of discoloration due to high bacterial activity.
 

2. Gas Formation:

  • Gas production leads to bloating, with gases like carbon dioxide, methane, and hydrogen sulfide.
 

3. Liquefaction of Tissue:

  • Tissues become liquefied, losing structural integrity, contributing to the characteristic odor of decomposition.
 

Timing of Discoloration:

  • Discoloration begins within 12-18 hours in summer and 1-2 days in winter, influenced by temperature and bacterial activity.

questions.text: A body was discovered in a lake near a village, and it needs to be determined whether the individual was alive at the time of drowning or if the body was dumped postmortem. Which of the following postmortem signs would most likely help in distinguishing between the two situations?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Also known as the boxing attitude, pugilistic attitude, or fencing attitude, occurs when the body is exposed to extreme temperatures (≥65°C).

Mechanism

Coagulation of muscle proteins, similar to how proteins coagulate when cooked.

Features
  • The body adopts a flexed attitude with stiff joints.
  • Hyperextended neck.
  • Claw-like fingers.
  • No normal rigor mortis is seen because the heat coagulates the proteins before rigor can occur.


 

Example

Observed in cases of individuals exposed to high temperatures, such as in a fire.

Definition

Cold stiffening occurs when the body is exposed to extremely low temperatures (≤-5°C).

Mechanism

Involves the freezing of body fluids and the hardening of subcutaneous tissues, creating stiffness in the body.

Features
  • Joints and tissues become stiff as the fluids in the body freeze.
  • Cold stiffening disappears when the body returns to normal temperatures, allowing normal rigor mortis to become apparent.

Example

Observed in cases of hypothermia or individuals exposed to extremely cold environments.

Definition

Gas stiffening occurs during decomposition as gases build up within the body.

Mechanism

Gas accumulation from bacterial activity in the intestines and other tissues.

Features
  • Stiffness in the body caused by bloating due to gas formation.
  • Protrusion of the tongue and eyeballs may occur due to internal pressure from gas.

Example

Often observed in bodies that have been deceased for a period, especially in warm environments that promote decomposition.

Definition

Cadaveric spasm, also known as cataleptic rigidity or instantaneous rigor, is an ante-mortem phenomenon occurring immediately at the time of death.

Mechanism

ATP depletion in a specific group of muscles that were contracted just before death.

Features
  • Muscles that were in use at the time of death remain stiff and rigid immediately after death.
  • No primary relaxation phase, but secondary relaxation occurs during decomposition.
  • Cannot be artificially induced, making it an exclusively ante-mortem finding.

Medico-Legal Importance

Cadaveric spasm helps in determining whether drowning was ante-mortem or post-mortem.

In cases of antemortem drowning, the spasm can cause the victim to tightly grip objects like weeds or mud, indicating they were alive and struggling before death. This provides evidence of active efforts during the drowning process.



 

Conversely, if no cadaveric spasm is present, it may suggest post-mortem immersion, indicating that the body was placed in water after death.

Feature

Cadaveric Spasm

Rigor Mortis

Time of Onset

Immediately after death

1-2 hours after death

Duration

Very brief; lasts until the body is manipulated or disturbed

Can last from several hours to days, depending on environmental factors

Involved Muscles

Mainly affects voluntary muscles; typically involves specific groups of muscles (e.g., hand muscles)

Involves both voluntary and involuntary muscles throughout the body

Primary Relaxation

Absent

Present

Molecular Death

Absent

Present

Electronic Stimuli

Response can be observed; indicates potential physical struggle

No response; indicates complete loss of muscular activity

Appearance

Muscles may appear tense and contracted, reflecting the last voluntary movement

Body becomes stiff and rigid, with a characteristic posture

Importance

Describes the manner of death, often indicating a sudden or violent death; can suggest defensive actions

Helps determine time since death.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions can lead to early onset rigor mortis? Cholera Strychnine poisoning Tetanus Asphyxia Pneumonia
questions.explanation:
Condition

Mechanism

Early Onset

Violent Death

Rapid muscle activity and ATP depletion due to trauma (e.g., firearms, cut throat).

Chronic Wasting Diseases

Muscle wasting leads to lower ATP reserves (e.g., tuberculosis, cholera).

Poisoning

Toxins (e.g., strychnine, cyanide) and conditions (e.g., tetanus) increase muscle contractions, depleting ATP.

Heat Stroke

Elevated body temperature accelerates biochemical reactions, promoting ATP depletion.

Late Onset

Asphyxia

Insufficient oxygen during death slows ATP production, delaying rigor mortis.

Pneumonia and Hemorrhage

Impaired oxygenation and circulation reduce energy production at death.

No Rigor Mortis

Extreme Cold

Hypothermia significantly reduces metabolic processes, potentially delaying rigor mortis.

Decomposing Bodies

Rapid decomposition hinders the development of rigor mortis.

Rigor Mortis in Fetus

Fetuses younger than 7 months lack developed actin and myosin filaments, preventing rigor mortis.

questions.text: According to the Bishop's tripod of life, which of the following is not a criterion for establishing death?

A 32-year-old male with a known history of chronic alcohol abuse was found unconscious at home. He was noted to have respiratory depression, pinpoint pupils, and altered mental status upon initial examination. Despite prompt resuscitation efforts, he succumbed to his condition. A postmortem examination revealed that the body had turned a dark black color. What is the most likely cause of death?
questions.explanation:
Condition

Color

Explanation

Normal (Natural Death)

Bluish-Purple

Deoxygenated blood pooling in the lower body parts.

Opium Poisoning

Black

Respiratory depression leads to severe hypoxia, causing a black discoloration.

Carbon Monoxide (CO) Poisoning (Option B)

Cherry Red

Formation of carboxyhemoglobin, which gives a bright red hue to the blood.

Hydrogen Sulfide (HS) Poisoning (Option A)

Bluish-Green

Sulfhemoglobin is formed due to HS exposure, causing a blue-green staining.

Cyanide Poisoning

Bright Red / Brick Red

Cyanide prevents cells from using oxygen, keeping blood highly oxygenated, giving a bright red color.

Phosphorus, Aniline, Nitrite, Bromide Poisoning

Dark Brown

These agents cause methemoglobinemia, where hemoglobin becomes oxidized, resulting in a dark brown color.

Methanol Poisoning (Option C)

Purple

Acidosis from methanol metabolism leads to a purple discoloration.

Hypothermia

Pink

Cold slows metabolism, preserving oxygen in the blood, which leads to a pinkish color.

Clostridium welchii Infection (Septic Abortion)

Bronze

Bacterial toxins cause hemolysis, leading to bronze-colored staining.

Phosphorus and Chloroform Poisoning

Yellow

Severe liver damage causes jaundice, leading to a yellow tint in postmortem staining.

Strychnine Poisoning

Intense Purple

Muscle rigidity and asphyxia result in extreme oxygen deprivation, causing a deep purple discoloration.

questions.text: A body has been presented to the forensic department for autopsy, exhibiting typically visible post-mortem changes given below as an image, including blanching and a shift of pattern occurring upon handling and moving the body. Based on these observations, what is the approximate time of death?
questions.explanation:
Onset

Begins approximately 30 minutes after death. Initially unfixed and can shift with body position changes.

Visibility

Becomes visibly apparent within 4 hours and reaches maximum intensity between 6-12 hours.

Fixation

Typically it becomes fixed by around 8 hours (between 6-12 hours). Staining won't move after fixation.

Confirmation Test

Apply pressure to the area:

 
  • Blanching indicates blood is still within vessels, staining is not yet fixed.
  • No blanching means staining is fixed, indicating breakdown of vessels and leakage into tissues.

Definition

Areas of the body where postmortem staining is absent due to vessel compression from tight contact with surfaces or objects.

Causes

Tight clothing or pressure points such as the occiput, shoulder blades, gluteal region, and calf region.

Mechanism

Blood vessels are compressed, preventing blood from pooling and causing the absence of postmortem staining.

Difference from Postmortem Staining

It is not fixed and can shift with movement as pressure points change, unlike postmortem staining, which becomes fixed once it sets.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is discovered deceased in his apartment. During examination, livor mortis is observed primarily on the front part of his body, as illustrated below. What was the most likely position of the body at the time of death based on this distribution of livor mortis?
questions.explanation:
Other Names

Postmortem staining, subcutaneous hypostasis, cadaveric lividity, suggillations, cogitation, vibices, and darkening of death.

Definition

Bluish or purplish-red discoloration caused by the gravitational settling of blood in the toneless capillaries and venules of the dependent parts of the dead body.

Site

Superficial layers of the dermis

Mechanism

Blood in capillaries and venules → Stagnates and sinks in dependent parts due to gravity → Bluish purple discoloration due to deoxy hemoglobin.

Begins

0.5 - 1 hour

Fully Developed

Within 4 hours

Fixation of Livor Mortis

Typically, within 6-12 hours

Confirmation of Fixation

Apply thumb pressure against the skin for a few seconds → Blanching → Livor mortis not fixed.

Primary Lividity

Occurs as lividity reaches maximum intensity between 6 to 12 hours after death.

Secondary Lividity

Shifting of lividity can occur if the body is moved within a few hours after death.

Duration of Persistence

Staining persists until putrefaction begins.

Distribution

Depends on position of the body:

Supine (Option B)

Appears on the back of neck, entire back, flanks, except areas under pressure (contact pallor).

Prone (Option A)

Appears on the front part of the body.

Side

Appears on the dependent side.

Head downwards (Option C)

Appears as a blackened face and neck.

Vertical suspension (Option D)

Appears on legs and hands (glove and stocking appearance) and external genitalia.

Drowning

Appears on the face, upper chest, hands, lower arms, feet, and calves.

Livor Mortis Absent

  • Excessive blood loss
  • Severe anemia
  • Death from wasting diseases
  • Lobar pneumonia

Medicolegal Importance
  • Helps estimate time of death.
  • Indicates body posture at death.
  • Indicates if the body was moved post-death.
  • Distribution may indicate the cause of death.

Image

 

Aspect

Contusion

Livor Mortis

Cause

Ruptured vessels that may be deep or superficial.

Distension of vessels with blood in the dermis.

Site

  • At the site of and surrounding the injury.
  • May appear anywhere in the body.

Over extensive areas of the most dependent parts.

Appearance

Swollen.

No elevation of the affected area.

Epidermis

May be abraded.

Not abraded.

Margins

Merge with the surrounding area.

Clearly defined.

Color

Different colors according to the age of the bruise.

Uniform, bluish-purple.

Incision

  • Extravasation of blood into surrounding tissues and are firmly clotted.
  • Subcutaneous tissues are deep reddish-black.
  • Blood is seen in blood vessels.
  • Subcutaneous tissues are pale.

questions.text: A forensic pathologist is examining the body of a 50-year-old male found deceased under suspicious circumstances, with elevated core temperature within two hours after death. Which of the following conditions is not typically associated with this postmortem finding?
questions.explanation:
1. Disturbed heat regulation
  1. Increased heat production (excessive muscle contraction)
  1. Excessive bacterial activity
  • Sunstroke
  • Pontine hemorrhage (Option D)
  • Tetanus (Option B)
  • Strychnine poisoning
  • Septicaemia (Option C)
  • Cholera

questions.text: A forensic investigator examines a body in a room at 22°C. The normal body temperature is 37°C, and the rectal temperature is 31°C. The rate of temperature fall is approximately 0.6°C per hour. What is the estimated time since death?

A forensic investigator is examining a 45-year-old male found deceased in his apartment. To determine the time of death using algor mortis, which of the following sites is ideal for measuring core body temperature?
questions.explanation:
Algor mortis

  • Refers to the cooling of the body after death, where the core body temperature equilibrates with the surrounding environment.
  • First detectable sign of death, followed by rigor mortis.

Onset

About 30 minutes to 1 hour after death.

Mechanism

Death → Heat loss (conduction, convection, radiation, evaporation) → ↓Body core temperature

Sites for Core Temperature Measurement
  • Rectum (8-10 cm above the anus): Ideal site for measurement except in cases of sodomy. (Option B)
  • External auditory meatus (Option D)
  • Subhepatic region (Option C)
  • Nostrils (up to the cribriform plate) (Option A)
  • Intracerebral (through the orbit)

Instruments for Core Temperature Measurement
  • Thanatometer/Chemical thermometer: 25 cm long thermometer with a range of 0 to 50°C.
  • Electronic thermocouple with a digital readout

Timing of Reading

Body temperature readings and environmental temperature should be recorded at 1 to 2-hour intervals to obtain the rate of fall of temperature.

Effect of Illness on Cooling

In serious illness, circulation begins to fail before death, causing hands and feet to cool before the rest of the body.

Medicolegal Importance

Inner core temperature measurements are important for estimating the time since death and are more reliable than surface temperature measurements.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is found dead in his apartment with no signs of external trauma. Based on the provided image of the eye showing hazy corneas and sunken eyeballs, what is the most likely time since death?
questions.explanation:
Part of Eye

Features

Time Since Death (TSD)

Retina

  • Kevorkian Sign: Fragmentation or segmentation of blood column in retinal vessels (cattle trucking or shunting)
  • Occurs within minutes and lasts about an hour.
  • Seen using an opthalmoscope.

Few minutes

Vitreous Humor
  • Vitreous humor’s accessibility and resistance to putrefaction make it ideal for forensic analysis.
  • Potassium along with hypoxanthine increases due to autolysis of choroid and retinal cells.
  • Potassium levels provide accurate TSD estimates, unaffected by external factors.
  • The Sturner and Gantner formula is used to estimate TSD from potassium levels.

-

Sclera

  • Tache Noire: Appears as two yellow triangles on the sclera (base on limbus, apex at medial or lateral canthus), which darken to brown and then black.
  • Caused by desiccation and deposition of cellular debris, mucus, and dust on exposed conjunctiva and the sclera underneath.
  • Forms if eyelids remain open for 3-4 hours postmortem.

3 - 4 hours

Cornea

  • Cornea becomes hazy within 2 hours of death due to drying and dust deposition.
  • Delayed for about 2 hours if lids are closed after death.
  • Transient haziness can be removed by applying water, but permanent opacity occurs after 10-12 hours due to decomposition.

Within 2 hours

Eyeball

  • Eyes appear sunken and become softer within minutes due to reduced intraocular tension.
  • Intraocular pressure drops from 10-22 mmHg during life to zero within 2 hours.

Within 2 hours (IOP becomes zero)

questions.text: The appearance of facial pallor after death is an example of which category of postmortem changes?
questions.explanation:
Changes After Death

Immediate Changes

(Option A)

Early Changes

(Option B)

Late Changes

(Option C)

Irreversible cessation of:

  • Brain function
  • Circulation
  • Respiration
  • Loss of elasticity of the skin
  • Facial pallor
  • Primary muscle relaxation
  • Contact pallor and flattening
  • Changes in the eyes
  • Algor mortis
  • Livor mortis
  • Rigor mortis
  • Putrefaction
  • Adipocere formation
  • Mummification

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is brought dead to the hospital. The doctor ties a ligature around the base of the fingers and notices no bluish discoloration or edema. Which test is the doctor using to check for the absence of circulation?
questions.explanation:
Tests to Detect Stoppage of Respiration
  • Winslow's Test: A mirror or a surface of water placed on the chest shows no movement or reflection of light.
  • Feather Test: A feather or fine cotton fibers held in front of the nostrils show no movement.
  • Mirror Test: A mirror held near the mouth and nostrils shows no haziness, indicating no exhalation.

Tests to Detect Stoppage of Circulation
  • Magnus Test (Ligature Test): No bluish discoloration or edema appears on the fingers when a ligature is applied at their base. (Option B)
  • Diaphanous Test (Transillumination Test): The web space between the fingers fails to show redness when transilluminated from behind. (Option C)
  • Icard's Test: Injected fluorescein dye does not produce yellowish-green discoloration, unlike in a living person. (Option A)
  • Pressure Test: Fingernails remain pale and do not turn reddish after applying and releasing firm pressure. (Option D)

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is declared dead after a cardiac arrest. 2 hours later, a forensic expert strikes the quadriceps with a reflex hammer and observes contraction. What does this indicate about the state of the patient’s tissues?

options.label: B
options.text: Muscle tissues have lost all responsiveness

questions.text: Suspended animation is most likely to occur after which type of poisoning?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Somatic Death

Molecular Death

Definition

Complete and irreversible cessation of brain function, circulation, and respiration

Progressive disintegration of body tissues, leading to the death of individual cells.

Onset

Occurs before molecular death.

Follows somatic death, occurring 1-2 hours after vital functions cease.

Tissue Viability

Tissues and cells remain alive and functioning.

Tissues and cells are dead and non-functioning, with no metabolic activity.

Response to Stimuli

Muscles can respond to thermal, electrical, or chemical stimuli.

No response to external stimuli.

Confirmation

Identified by flat ECG and EEG readings, and absence of breath sounds

Confirmed through rigor mortis, algor mortis, postmortem staining, and putrefaction.

Resemblance

May resemble conditions like suspended animation, coma, or hypothermia.

Does not resemble any other condition.

Suspended Animation (Apparent Death)

Suspended animation refers to a condition where vital signs, such as heartbeat and respiration, are undetectable using standard clinical methods due to temporary interruption or reduction of these functions to minimal levels.

 

Mechanism

  • The metabolic rate significantly decreases, allowing cells to meet their oxygen needs through dissolved oxygen in body fluids.
 

Types

  • Voluntary: Occurs in individuals practicing yoga or in trance states.
  • Involuntary: Occurs in conditions like hypothermia, barbiturate (Option D) or opiate poisoning, newborns, drowning, electrocution, heatstroke, cholera, post-anesthesia, shock, cerebral concussion, or insanity.
 

Management

  • Resuscitation can be achieved using cardiac massage, electrical stimulation, and artificial respiration.
  • An ECG or EEG is required before issuing a death certificate to confirm death.
